As a hypermobile person who really enjoys gymnastics I can say that it doesn’t bring only positives, as it makes it much easier to dislocate parts of the body and sprain ligaments, It also makes it take longer to recover from muscular pains after workouts, and it increases your chances of having asthma, for example. One thing that I don’t see people talk much about is how hard it is to learn to write while having hypermobility, since our hands don’t grip in the same way it makes it really painful to write for long periods of time, and specially when you’re learning, writing stuff will take longer and your hand writing will be terrible, which made my parents put me in calligraphy lessons, that lead to me going to physiotherapy for a whole semester when I was young.

This video only briefly mentioned the Beighton Score, and what this video failed to mention that it's used to determine whether one has the presence and severity of symptoms associated with Ehler Danlos Syndrome, which can manifest through abnormal hypermobility of various joints. ED with hypermobility is NOT a desirable condition, it is an actual handicap which can lead to a range of other conditions and put the sufferer at risk of frequent injury.

I really enjoy the content on Physics Girl's channel. However, I must say that this video is sharing outdated information on the science of stretching.

It doesn't take much research to learn that the difference between a stiff muscle and a flexible one is not the length of the muscle, but is instead the result of a neurological phenomenon. Your weak muscles and lack of coordination in a range of motion you have never explored before makes your brain not trust you to flex your muscles in their full range of motion. So your brain makes those muscles contract to prevent you from going all the way and potentially hurting yourself.

To gain "flexibility" is really to gain "trust" from your nervous system by strengthening the muscles around the joint whose range of motion you are trying to increase. "Stretching" is really just an lightweight isometric hold that is strengthening the muscle being stretched. A more effective way to strengthen that muscle and make it more "flexible" would be to use weights or other forms of resistance and contract the muscle like you would workout any other muscle.

I'm naturally hypermobile, and it is NOT great.  When I was about 15, I had an orthopedist tell me I'd tighten up as I age, and he was right.  Spent my teens and 20s in agonizing back pain because my vertebrae (and all my ball and socket joints) slip out as they wish.  30s and 40s were pain free.  50's starting to get stiff like regular people, and I'll start to stretch like regular people, although I occasionally dislocate a rib, which reminds me I"ll never be like "regular people."  With everything, seek balance in the middle, meaning don't strive to to weird things.  It's never good for you.

A lot of people that qualify as hypermobile, and many contortionists, have Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome. Unfortunately, those of us with this disease experience a lot of side effects that can be debilitating, painful, and wreak havoc on many aspects of their lives. For eg. greater tendency to experience muscle pulls/tears/spasms, dislocations/subluxations, along with organ issues (including skin) and other comorbid diseases such as Chiari malformation, ASD, postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome, etc. If you experience severe pain, have "popping" of joints and are hypermobile it's definitely worth bringing it up with a doctor before considering going into sports like this as it may worsen symptoms.

It’s very interesting and biomechanical analysis of how the body achieves increase flexibility, there’s just an assumption that more flexibility is healthier. That is not implicitly correct.  There’s a reason that hyperflexibility hyper mobility is a medical term. At some point increase flexibility is actually detrimental to the tissues as you need stability for protection of the tissue and joint. Just because you CAN become that Flexible doesn’t mean that you should

The problem is- when people like Sophie get old, the back muscles no longer support the spine, and the soft tissues are not as elastic anymore as they used to be. The result is often a condition called spondylolisthesis (gliding vertebrae) which is painful and sometimes even leads to paralysis. I‘m a doctor and I‘ve seen quite a people that needed surgery.

There is one serious FLAW in this video (and that study, which probably didn't even consider this method, since not a lot of people don't even know about it)...
- The actual BEST and Fastest method of Flexibility is NOT "static/passive" it's "static/active". In other words, you go into your static stretch, and then you "tense" the muscles being stretched for about 5 seconds, relax and then you go a little "further" into the stretch repeating for about 5 times. This method will massively both increase the speed in which you get highly flexible, and it will considerably increase the degree of your flexibility compared to simple static stretching.

I used to be a contortionist... and gymnast and all around athlete. Being flexible was natural, I could do splits from my first class. I'm 45 and I can still drop into splits with no warm up. I had a great muscle structure, as an athlete and I never really lost it even when I gained weight with my child. But an accident in my 30s left me immobile for a year. I lost a lot of muscle mass and then ended up with intense pain, all day every day, almost bed bound. It wasn't until a specialist noticed me flexing my wrists and cracking my joints that she gave me the Beighton test, I scored 9/9. She diagnose me with Type 3 Elhers Danlos Syndrome after 3 years of looking for an answer.

I also have CFS, Fibro, osteoarthritis and POTS but I'm still active as I can be, most don't notice I'm in pain. But since that accident my muscles have tightened up so I have to be careful to keep them warm and take muscle relaxers all day. It's a crazy disease! There's more than I can tell in a YouTube comment.

Great and all but as someone with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome (faulty collagen), hypermobility and flexibility are VERY different. I have been a contortionist and I am now a regular person, it's all about conditioning. For example, I can dislocate my hip by rotating it (joint hypermobility) however I can't do the splits anymore (joint flexibility). Flexibility does not cause instability in the joint, I was far stronger when I was flexible, now that I'm not, my joints fall apart far too easily. I even have to wear metal splints on my hands to stop the finger joints from dislocating. Flexibility is not genetic, it's trained, anyone can be flexible.

Beighton score is used to diagnose EDS too.. I feel like this was glazed over, and being really flexible could also come with organ fragility, pots, etc... Eds is a lifelong chronic pain condition. I wish they touched on this more

But focusing on flexibility without strength can result in injury! I am living proof with a pulled hamstring attachment this video is very dangerous. It encourages dangerous stretching and tendons and ligaments are NOT elastic, meaning once you stretch them, they cannot go back so I also have a pulled shoulder from a pole class so now I have to work very hard to keep it in the socket with muscle instead of tendons and ligaments so this is a daily practice to stay out of pain or worse, surgery. These injuries lead me to become a yoga instructor but that still does not address  hypermobility where I am injuring myself. Even my arms were in pain in downdog from this and until I found Anthony Bennenati @thatsnotyoga, no one could explain this and that's after years of searching and also physical therapy. Now after years I enjoy teaching but it is still really interesting that so many people do not address this and that's what lead me here. I want more information which this gave some of but to promote people over stretching is VERY dangerous! #1 rule is flexibility without strength can lead to injury. It is amazing to me to watch contortionists like this but they started very young while they were still growing so their bodies may have different collagen and after 12 years of dedicated yoga practice I am more mobile but before I found Anthony to explain the dangers of hyper extension, I was in pain in my arms and hips and even knees.

My testimony:
In my 5th decade, not a ballerina or gymnast growing up (foot arch and hip built wouldn’t allow). As I grew older I realized how tight my body became so I decided to take yoga 6 days a week in 2018 (yoga flow and iyengar) that lasted for about 7 months. I became more and more flexible. However I was too aggressive thus triggered an old shoulder blade injury. I stopped yoga for a year. I came back to yoga in January 2020. The first two weeks I was stiffer than when I was brand new to yoga. By 3 week I became stronger than when I quit yoga in Feb 2019. I have been concentrating on upper back, shoulder, side ribs, hamstring, and hip flexibility since I came back to yoga and the result has been unbelievable. I can finally do classic camel without leaning back. I can pancake also flat to the floor. The magic is breathing and let go of fear and control. The sensation of growing longer and sinking deeper is wonderful (no pain as soon as I let go and trust my body). Anyone can become more flexible and stronger but it does take time and intention. It feels really good to be mindful of my own body, alignment, and placement.

Beighton score has been superseded by other wider hypermobility criteria because you can be hypermobile without scoring anything on the test. First check out the Brighton criteria (yes, the confusing similarity in spelling is real, that's not autocorrect) but even that is limiting. Hypermobility is more nuanced than Beighton scale can show. If you think you have it don't be put off by Beighton score, look up hEDS and hypermobility spectrum. It can take a very long time to be diagnosed mostly because of awareness and partly because of rigidly (!) sticking to the Beighton score as only indicator.

What hasn't been pointed out is the myofascial connections through your whole body which work together and can actually change tension and shape through the myofibroblasts. This extends way further than only one muscle group, but through entire chains of fascia, muscle's and joints throught the whole body. In my experience as a physical therapist breath-release exercises speed up the process, because the myofibroblasts wil instantly change the line of pull if addressed correctly. This makes it possible to increase range of motion drastically in a matter of minutes without negative side effects! :D

As a old hyperflexible rhythmic gymnast and a biologist in the making, I found this video very interesting 😄 Now I know what is happening in my body 😅

·

What does science have to say about how to get more flexible?
·—·
{{K. Michael Rowley, PhD - USC Division of Biokinesiology and Physical Therapy}}
{{ https://pt.usc.edu/about-usc-biokinesiology-and-physical-therapy/faculty-directory-n-z/k-michael-rowley-phd/ }}
·—·
Well, Michael pointed me to this really interesting meta-analysis, which is like a big study that actually synthesizes all the findings from other studies, in this case, 23 other studies, which looked at how to get the best benefits on improved range of motion, or flexibility.
·—·
And they found that ☛☞ static stretching, that is when you ease into a stretch and then hold it for 30 to 60 seconds, that's the best for improved range of motion, or flexibility. ☜☚
·—·
And as far as how much to stretch, they found that ☛☞ five minutes total per week of one muscle group ☜☚ was sort of the lower limit.
·—·
But you didn't see much more of a benefit over 10 minutes a week of stretching. And six days out of the week was the plateau of seeing returns.
·—·
So the more you stretch per day doesn't keep increasing the benefits, but ☛☞ that frequency, six days a week and then the five minutes total for that week, is what's important. ☜☚
·—·
Source: 05:15 onwards http://youtube.com/watch?t=315s&v=1JgBp7dX4AU

Static stretching and holding is the WORST thing you can do. You NEVER find yourself posing in a specific position and then staying there. Your body is always moving, so when you stretch, you should bounce back to your starting position. Your brain detects the damage done by a static hold, and it doesn't want to get damaged in the future, so it makes your muscles NOT activate so that you go near that first static stretch/hold. You see this, and struggle against it, creating even more damage to your muscles.

No, no no! Hypermobility and hyperflexibility are two VERY DIFFERENT THINGS.

I have Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, which means I am hypermobile. I have defective collagen. Hypermobility is genetic, you're born with it. It can also be debilitating. I for example dislocate my joints hundreds of times a day, I have to wear metal splints on my fingers to stop my fingers from dislocating every time I pick up a pencil. The hypermobility doesn't just affect joints either, it's skin, hair.... Even organs. My hypermobility has paralysed my stomach, so I can never eat solid food again. It's also caused brain fluid to leak from my nose, it also makes me pass out when I stand up sometimes.

As you can tell, there's a massive distinction between hypermobility and flexibility already.

Flexibility is from stretching, this is what contortionists do. They condition their joints to get used to this. I used to be a contortionist until I had to stop. Flexibility is not debilitating, you can go about your life normally when you're not purposely stretching. Flexibility is the result of training, you aren't born with it.

Hi! Actually, the question is largely wrong. Stretching is mental, not physical. If someone is unconscious, they can do the splits without any problem. That is why picking up an unconscious person is so difficult. The mind protects the body from unsafe positions by making us stiff. Stretching trains the mind that these positions are safe. Strangely, one of the best and safest ways to stretch is not by relaxing but by flexing the muscle that you want to stretch. Flexing the muscle tells the brain, "I'm okay. There is supposed to be a slight pain when you really stretch but the more you relax the better it is. MAKE SURE YOU WARM UP. Do jumping jacks or something to get your heart rate up. If you try to stretch to deep without warming up you could injure yourself. My team was stretching before track practice and on of our 200 meter runners nearly tore his quad stretching because he was too stiff. It agonizing stuff to injure yourself that way anything that has to do with athleticism make sure your body is prepared to be pushed. He was a very muscular person so also take that into account. The beefier you are the more you may want to warm up. If you don’t know how much to warm up you should just feel like you’re body heat is about to make you start sweating but you’re not. That phase between dry calmness and sweaty exhaustion where your just glistening. You shouldn’t be breathing hard and your skin shouldn’t be wet with sweat. Just maybe breathing a little faster than normal. Maybe Three sets of 30 Jumping Jacks with a 10 second rest between each. Or do dynamic stretches for the group you want to stretch for a minute. Dynamic stretches are the ones you don’t hold. Like outing your hands straight out and doing high kicks to you hands. It will prepare your muscles with shorter bursts of stretches and it well warm you up because it requires repetitive motion that’s more than what you normally do walking around. Unless you walk like Frankenstein that is.

Stretch your arms and shoulders. Start your stretching regimen either standing or sitting on the edge of a sturdy chair. If you're going to stretch your arms and shoulders while sitting, make sure you're sitting with good posture. 

Keep your back straight and neutral with your shoulder blades tucked down in line with your spine.

 [5]

Reach one arm straight across your chest, pressing gently with your other hand just above your elbow until you feel a stretch. Don't push your arm to force it further than it naturally goes. Hold the stretch for about 5 seconds, breathing deeply. Then release and do the other arm.

Lift one arm overhead and bend your elbow, dropping your hand behind your head. Grasp your fingers from below with the other hand if you can. If you can't, place your other hand below your elbow and push back gently until you feel a stretch in your triceps. Hold the stretch for about 5 seconds, then switch and do the other arm.

Sofie has an exceptionally high level of motor control and proprioception.  Neurologically, Sofie uses sensory input to generate the appropriate levels of force throughout her body via the muscular system to move her skeletal system.  From a physics perspective, the skeletal system are levers and muscles are pullys which are controlled by the nervous system.  Movement is a skill that everyone can and should improve.  Another way to look at it is when your body executes a move correctly, it is coordinated movement.  If your body doesn’t execute a move correctly, it is uncoordinated.  Movement skills and attributes are acquired through motor learning and practice.  Sofie is unusually hypermobile and I wouldn’t suggest any of the contortionist positions which could be unsafe for most people.  But everyone can improve the way they move.  And you could certainly learn the move you attempted at the end of the video.

DANGER !!!  1. Over-stretching !!!  When tendons and ligaments don't hold you together, you are prone to dislocations - bones popping out from where they belong.  You want elasticity, you don't want nothing-holding-you-together.   2. Anyone paralyzed yet?  Spinal cord injuries if you even aim for what's shown here!  3. Vertebrae - 99.9% of people can't do half what Sofie does without damaging the bones of the spine - see their different shapes at different regions of the spine - different vertebrae allow for different kinds of motion - none allow for this amount of contortion.  4.  Over-stretching part 2:  An elastic body is an efficient body, allowing for easy and graceful movement.  You want to be elastic, not gangly.   5. Desensitization - many dancers and yogis love what they feel at the extremes of their range of motion - the body is sending alarms but to them it feels exciting.  They crave that feeling so they go past integration and flexibility into distortion and damage.  You want to develop subtle sensitivity to maximum power and freedom (i.e. feeling joint integrity, where forces go into structures), not lack of body awareness.   @Physics_Girl, this is seriously irresponsible.   Will you address these issues?  If you want references (publications and/or interviewees), let me know.

I find that if I meditate before and during my stretching it helps to not feel so much of the pain. I try to relax my mind as much as possible. As I pull on the muscle, I slowly breath a deep breath out as I let my entire body relax as much as I can. Any time I start to feel the pain again, I remind my body that it needs to be soft and not resisting. Opposite of flex. Not tight. Almost the same as when I am trying to fall asleep. Breath out... fall asleep.... As I pull the stretch, I let my mind lean into that "sleepy place."
An example: Breath in deep breath, grab foot, as you pull your body low to the floor breath out, hold the stretch and slowly breath in (I usually feel the stretch pain a little more during the in breath), very slowly pull the stretch a little bit more and breath out slowly(as I breath out the pain subsides)...keep the stretch and as you breath out relax completely, breath in...
I try to do this until I can feel the muscle that I'm working loosen up and get a little softer. I very gently pull a little more and hold there as long as I can. usually about one minute when I am just getting back into it and then as the days go on my times get longer.
This method works well for me, I hope I help someone with their stretching. It's so good for us and makes our lives better and our moods better but stretching can be a little intimidating at first. But once you get through the first few times it starts to feel better. After a little while it actually starts to feel great. I wish I could explain how it feels but the pleasure that stretching gives to a person who stretches every day is a feeling that feels like nothing else. So all I can say is is feels really good!
Happy Stretching😄!

Science is tested, and then information is updated often. So, some additional information to seek (no particular order):
Shallow hip socket versus deep hip socket and how that changes ROM (thigh/hip rom) between individuals. This shows how anatomy, which cannot be changed organically, effects an individual's ROM. We are all genetically different and must appreciate our gifts, and respect our limits.
Seek the ROM chart that physiotherapists and physical therapists use, which provides general guidelines for each joint's healthy ROM. Learn as much as you can about anything you want to achieve (not via YouTube or social media... Find another method of knowledge-gathering, and invest).
Lastly, learn about the amount of education required (book study and lecture hours as well as practicum hours) to even qualify to sit for a licensure exam that then allows a person to help someone increase their individual ROM, safely, and by using multiple protocols.

Stretching really is good for you, when it is performed correctly. Stretching can really harm you if it is not done properly. I encourage everyone to work with a qualified practitioner (many personal trainers take CEUs on stretching), and find a good licensed massage therapist and chiropractor. These three individuals can help you stay healthy while you're increasing your ROM.

Something I didn't see this video cover was active flexibility and the important role that plays in gaining flexibility. The way I understand it, if you only passively stretch, it might not do much for you, or could even make your flexibility worse, if you damage the nerves (nerves don't stretch the same as muscle). My resource for this is Dr. Jen Crane, a physiotherapist for circus artists. Cirque_Physio on Facebook, and @Cirque_Physio on Instagram.

I wouldn’t say that stretching all those tendons and ligaments is a good thing as especially ligaments are meant to be the stabilizers of the body. Also there is a difference between having and maintaining full ROM for general population vs a contortion practice. Two totally different aspects that are getting compounded in this vid, as the word “flexibility” is used interchangeably at times referring to gen pop and other times referring to contortion practice. As “amazing” as this is, the overstretched ligamentous structures loose good functionality in doing what they need to do at an optimal level as time goes by and in future years. I hope this vid doesn’t incite individuals to aimlessly start engaging in contortion because they think it is “healthy” Bc that’s far from the truth.

I was the most inflexible young person...then I saw this girl in gym class that could do crazy things...so for two months I did nothing but stretch beyond the pain slowly.  What I was feeling was slow tears in my muscles and ligaments... I remember how I would walk funny till it healed and I became flexible.  Now, to this day I maintained the flexibility even 30 years later. I can take a running jump in the air and land into a split on the hard wood floor with zero pain.  Most people have pain avoidance so the believe they cannot be flexible...This is false.  It really did not take more than two months...  stretching feels really good now.

Fact: Most people can't do a "side split" (flat on the floor with legs out to the side, toes up), but virtually everyone can stand and move a single leg at a time 90 degrees out to the side (with toes up) and rest it on a table, say -- YET, there is utterly NO anatomical connection between the legs thus, in principle, almost anyone can do a full side split (if you can do both sides, one at a time, you can do both at the same time). The reason? The "reflex effect" mentioned in the video: when your split goes farther than you are "used to" your brain immediately tells the muscles to contract to inhibit further movement. Most people can be physically FORCED into a side stretch by a coach (please DO NOT TRY THIS!!!!) and then, almost immediately, that particular stretch reflex is over-written neurologically to allow the full split.

It is important to point out you should not force yourself too much or you'll risk injuring yourself. Once it start hurting a little back off a little, hold the position just a little beyond the point where it stops being comfortable but don't torture yourself; you need to have patience, keep track of how stretchy you are and check again every week or so, it's not an overnight thing but often little by people can make themselves way more flexible over time. But if you injure yourself, that might mess up your training, so don't push yourself too hard, just a little.

One thing Sophie might want to consider is whether she has a condition called 'Ehlers Danlos Syndrome' (EDS), particularly as she was uber-flexible prior to starting contortion. This syndrome is said to be shared by a very high proportion of contortionists and basically means the collagen in your ligaments 'breaks down' over time, so every time you stretch them, they don't quite come back to how they were to start with. It's incremental, muscularly, but as you well know, adding a minuscule thing, over time, gives you something substantial, eventually.
Do you know whether Sophie has EDS? (and whether she'll allow you to divulge that info)
I have EDS, it's genetic, and my daughter has it too, but my son doesn't. :)
I used to be able to contort into some very interesting positions, but can't anymore. Getting old with EDS is not always great, particularly if you have other aligned issues (PM me if you want more info).

I have hypermobility syndrome. I have had it since I was very young. It has caused a lot of problems in my life as well as a lot of other people's lives. I'm 19 and will have chronic back pain partially caused by this disease. It's not really much to joke about and I warn people daily of the dangers of hyper extending your joints. It tears joint tissue and can cause massive swelling in the joints. One morning I woke up with knees the size of cantaloupes and I couldn't bend them at all. To make the rest of this story short, I ended up in a lower body cast to keep my legs straight and I was diagnosed with hypermobility. It is a lot of physical therapy and a lot of work to get your body to be stronger when you have hyper flexible joints. I spent years in and out of physical therapy with stacks of exercises to do to strengthen basically every muscle in my body. I did muscle stimulation therapy and tense therapy and even after all of that I will still never be able to play a contact sport without fear of hurting myself. I basically live in a permanent slightly vulnerable state.

Not to be a downer, but there's disadvantages in taking it too far.  I have a friend with Ehlers-Danlo Syndrome, which is where a genetic defect creates hypermobility of varying degrees, up to the most extreme sort.  When younger, some folks can be contortionists; when older, they can dislocate bones accidentally to the point of permanent constant injury.  As in, "dislocate shoulders by turning in bed" type of difficulties.  They can also have connective-tissue problems with the cartilage in organs like the heart.  Early diagnosis is better for avoiding injury and getting treatment.  I'd advise anybody who's clearly hypermobile to get tested for this.

she's the physics girl, and this is from the physio girl: stretching does NOTHING to prevent injury or improve performance in strength/power/agility/endurance sports, however being hyperflexibile can predispose to you joint misalignment, maladapted static and dynamic compensations and arthritis in the long run. And also, if you over stretch ligaments, joint capsules, there is NOTHING you can do to reverse it (unless you want to do surgery). So if you have all the range of motion to do everything you need to do in your life, you DO NOT need to stretch. It does not add anything positive to your health.

Great video,and the summary was good. I will add that more mobility in tendons and ligaments is not necessarily a good thing. You need to make sure that you are stretching out the muscles proportionately.  I know people that are hyper-flexible who have had to have their connective tissue surgically shortened because it was not protecting their muscles and joints enough and they were getting injured by that alpha gamma loop not being effective. In other words, the notion that naively increasing your flexibility is good for you is a common misconception, popular in yoga.. I have a friend that owns a scanning company for soft tissue injuries and he says he gets more  business from injuries done in yoga than anything else.

They didn’t mention that within the same stretching session, the length of time matters to increase muscle flexibility.
The muscle spindle fibers will tell the muscle to contract as a protective measure when a stretch is first initiated (which they did mention) and then in response to a sustained stretch (think 30-60 seconds), the golgi tendon organs (sensory organ within the muscle tendon) will allow the muscle to relax by inhibiting the protective contraction. The golgi tendon organ will then process the newly attained range of motion as the muscle’s normal length, thus leading to semipermanant changes in muscle length.

If you have such extreme flexibility, and she is far from alone, odds are high you actually have a rare genetic disorder called Ehler-Danlos Syndrome. There are a number of types and a fair amount of crossover between them. Given I have the condition as well as several of my children, we are quite familiar with it. Yes, I, and now they, are quite capable of exactly those sorts of movements, including the most extreme. Lots of fun when you are young but I have hit the downside of them, including severe joint instability to the point of needing a walker and wheelchair, continuous severe chronic pain from them, and because it turned out we have one of the more rare types along with the hypermobility, organ ruptures without trauma, aortic dissections, and hemorrhagic strokes. As cool and fun as that looks and sometimes is, there are thousands and millions of people that would give almost anything NOT to bend that way.

THIS IS CALLED EHLERS-DANLOS SYNDROME. It is diagnosed using the Beighton Score. I know this, because I have it. I score a 10/10 on the Beighton Score. Please do not hurt yourself trying to do these things. Only people who are GENETICALLY MUTATED can do things like this.

In fact, I’m kind of offended by this video. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome cases can range from no pain, to mild, to moderate, to severe, to critical. My case is extremely severe. It’s very painful. I am so hypermobile that my joints dislocate on the daily. That is what joint flexibility ultimately leads to.

Defective collagen, or having more stretchy collagen, is not always fun and games. The more she stretches, since she was born hypermobile, the more her joint cartilage will wear away. Which WILL BE PAINFUL when she gets older. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome may seem cool at first, but it can DEGENERATE your body, kind of like Rheumatoid Arthritis—which doesn’t feel good. It may not hurt now, but it will later in life.

Actually..... these people who are double jointed, and able to do this like she does in their older years will most likely have issues because this doesn't do no harm at all. It's like a runner who has problems with their knees way down the line after most of their life running.  A lot of people that perform for Cirque du Soleil end up retiring once their body hits their limits in their older age many end up with arthritis and the collagen they had so much of decreases and leaves them a little less flexible.  Working in the medical field, I've seen an older woman who could do contorting, but once she hit her 50's she started having aches and pains that ended up stopping what she loved doing and suffered damage over time to her spine and the bones. You can do healthy stretching, but always be mindful.... you can also seriously harm yourself and do damage that can be debilitating. It's about like people that are double-jointed, are more prone to eventually suffer a rotator cuff tear.... so these amazing things people can do with their bodies, can do a lot of harm over time depending on how often their unique talents are performed.

Another thing is that actually anyone can become "hyperflexible" like Sofie. The only problem is that for most people this would involve a lot of stretching (1-2 times per day) for a very long time (8-15 years or maybe even more), combined with a lot of exercising and the correct diet (you need much stronger muscles and more efficient lungs) and you must refrain from carrying large objects around (that cancels the effects of the stretching because to carry large object around you need a body that is NOT hyperflexible because then it doesn't need to spend so much energy on that activity). Especially the last item on this list is nearly impossible to do for most people because most jobs in the world contain a lot of "carrying of heavy objects around".

The point is that during that discipline the body will remodel itself to adapt to the load you are putting onto it. If the load is composed of stretching, the body will replace the stiff parts of the skeleton with the stretchy parts, making the skeleton and thus the body much more flexible.

A disadvantage of superflexible body like Sofie's is that her ability to carry heavy objects is severely reduced. The reason for that is that her skeleton provides no stable support so she needs to use her raw muscle power to force the heavy object to go where she wants instead of going where it wants (usually straight to the floor). Jobs like factory manipulant (a person who unpacks material and puts it onto the construction lines) at e.g. car factory are not compatible with a superflexible body. I think Sofie would last only about 2-3 hours on such a shift (or need to get an oxygen canister) while Diana would be able to handle a typical 8 hour shift just fine.

A warning for obsessive stretchers...
In my youth when I was running a lot (track & cross country in HS, 5k & 10k in college) and obsessed with flexibility because I thought it was part and parcel of general fitness, I was actually making certain tissues (in knees and shoulders, especially) too flexible where they wouldn't hold a joint in place enough to prevent injury. My advice is that warmups are far more important for activity preparation but mild stretching is still good so long as you monitor how far you're taking it. That said, some people are very tight in some areas, usually due to prolonged sitting or overexertion, and will benefit from hip openers and spinal twists as are popular in yoga.

Please read [health]: stretching is HARMFUL, long term, for hypermobile people! Ligaments are what holds all our joints together- once they're overstretched (as they naturally are a bit in hypermobile people) they can't go back. That means your muscles/tendons have to work harder to hold your body together. Many people with benign hypermobility (like the contortionist) develop hypermobility spectrum disorder- meaning musculoskeletal joint pain or recurrent injury at minimum- due to their muscles/tendons overcompensating for their bendy-ness. They are more susceptible to overuse injuries like carpal tunnel. If you're hypermobile (check beighton score) please take care of yourself by strengthening your core and muscles around joints and opting for self massage as opposed to further stretching. Most people are encouraged to become more flexible, but people with hypermobility need to kind of become firmer to hold themselves together without injury or future chronic pain. About 20% of people have hypermobility, so I think it's important to educate people on how to take care of their unique bodies.

Ugh... most of the time, science isn't really as methodically sound as it claims to be.

First off, you didn't even try to give an objective definition of what it means to stretch. And that's most likely due to the general assumption across scientists here being that if two human beings align their bodies in the 'same' spatial configuration that one would consider a typical stretch posture, they're actually stretching (and doing the same).

But there's way more parameters than time and simple skeletal posture to anything the body does. As far as stretching is concerned, modern science has to acknowledge: Effects of breathing, effects of thought, effects of mental attitude, mental imaging, diet/habits etc. etc.. Any assumption that these would be negligible is quite arbitrary.

What about running efficiency and flexibility? i.e. Paula Radcliffe's lower body flexibility deteriorated in some areas by up to 50%, but, at the same time, she became far more efficient and then set a new marathon world record at 2:15:25. Biomechanical researchers have raised the idea that too much flexibility might contribute to diminished running efficiency and slower times.
2. What about the long-term negative effects of being hypermobile/hyperflexible/having hyperlaxity? Although hypermobility is useful to many people (dancers, swimmers, pianists (finger joints), etc.) for some people there is an associated increase in things like muscle or joint pain, joint stiffness, injuries, stability problems, sense of proprioception problems, age-related increases in pain when stretching later in life, surgical recovery is more problematic and so on.
3. What about hamstring flexibility? The hamstring performs slightly differently to many other muscle groups in the body as in they are designed to be both long and tight. Flexibility requirements depend on the job of the muscles, tendons and ligaments in relation to the structural and movement necessities.

I wanted to add that there are some forms of hyper mobility that are actually disorders. In Ehlers Danlos Syndrome the dna encoding  collagen is actually  different and this causes problems throughout the body. Over-stretching and frequent stretching are very easy to do with EDS, but over time lead to more pain and joint instability. The Beighton score is actually used as one of the many diagnostic criteria’s. So have fun, be flexible, but don’t overdo it and if you can do all of those stretches without effort and have other health issues, consider speaking with a doctor.

Some missing info here. From doing yoga and being aware of anatomical function one can and will gain a body awareness of gaining functional flexibility. For instance touching one's toes or eventually touching palms to floor, start with focused breathing, bend over to a forward fold while keeping knees bent. Concentrate on the breath. Contract core muscles and focus on "hinging" at the hips. Fold more if possible while keeping knees bent. Attempt to contract  quadriceps. Be aware of bodily sensations. Back off from pain. Be aware of tightness in hamstrings, lower back, glute medius or glute maximus. Chances are certain muscle groups are not used to activation and other muscle groups have been carrying the load all along. Remember to breathe and engage the bandhas (you'll have to look that one up). This awareness is also a great form of meditation and stilling the mind. Leslie Kaminoff has some great insight into this. The problem with many (most) yoga instrucors is that the basic fundamentals are not explained. Regular practice will increase flexibility and allow one to understand one's body. Don't just overstretch!!! Hope this helps.

Hypermobility can be a disabling, such as in Ehlers Danlos Syndrome type 3. Hypermobile folks have to be vigilant to prevent hyperextending joints, which can lead to dislocations and chronic pain. Loose ligaments force hypermobile people to work much harder to do the same activities as the less flexible, like walking, because there is less spring back. Just because a person can bend themselves into a certain shape, doesn't mean they should--- and they certainly shouldn't be encouraging less flexible people to throw themselves into contortions.

Fun video; and your personality is really easy to keep watching. Here's some insight in to types of stretching... I don't believe that static stretching creates the greatest increase in flexibility. I've worked as a PT and an athletic trainer and was always taught (and I've seen the effect in the lab) of massive flexibility gains when you use PNF stretching (proprioceptive, neuromuscular facilitation). Basically you stretch to your limit, and then contract against resistance through a full range of motion. This will inhibit the muscle spindle fibers from protecting a muscle and will allow you to gain massive flexibility gains in as little as 1-2 minutes. These gains come almost exclusively from the muscle, and some in the tendon. If you're curious about this process just google PNF Stretching and see a demonstration. The hamstring group is a great example, just because of the large amount of muscle there (you can see a really big effect). Thanks for making such high-caliber videos! Can't wait to see more!
